sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving solids
message_1:
Calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction: 
2 Al(s) + 3/2 O2(g) → Al2O3(s) 
given the following information: 
ΔH°f[Al2O3(s)] = -1676.0 kJ/mol 
ΔH°f[Al(s)] = 0 kJ/mol 
ΔH°f[O2(g)] = 0 kJ/mol
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction, we can use the following equation:

ΔH°reaction = Σ ΔH°f(products) - Σ ΔH°f(reactants)

For this reaction, we have:

ΔH°reaction = [1 × ΔH°f(Al2O3)] - [2 × ΔH°f(Al) + 3/2 × ΔH°f(O2)]

Given the values for the standard enthalpies of formation:

ΔH°reaction = [1 × (-1676.0 kJ/mol)] - [2 × 0 kJ/mol + 3/2 × 0 kJ/mol]

ΔH°reaction = -1676.0 kJ/mol

So, the standard enthalpy change for the reaction is -1676.0 kJ/mol.
